column1: This list tracks and ranks the population of the top 10 largest cities and other urban places in the United States by decade
column2: as reported by each decennial United States Census
column3: starting with the 1790 Census. For 1790 through 1990
column4: tables are taken from the U.S Census Bureau's "Population of the 100 Largest Cities and Other Urban Places in the United States: 1790 to 1990." For year 2000 rankings
column5: data from the Census Bureau's tally of "Cities with 100
column6: 000 or More Population Ranked by Selected Subject" is used. The 2010 rankings are based on the 2010 census results.The Census Bureau's definition of an "urban place" has included a variety of designations
column12: and municipality. The top 10 urban areas in 1790 consisted of various places designated as cities
column13: towns and townships. The top 10 urban areas in 2010 are all separate incorporated places.

column1: This list generally refers only to the population of individual urban places within their defined limits at the time of the indicated census. Some of these places have since been annexed or merged into other cities. Other places may have expanded their borders due to such annexation or consolidation. For example
column2: after the 1898 consolidation of New York City
column3: the Census Bureau has defined all the boroughs within its city limits as one "urban place". Similarly
column4: Philadelphia's population has included the census counts within both the former urban areas of Northern Liberties

column1: When the United States first became a sovereign country in 1776
column2: Philadelphia was its most populous city. By the time the first U.S. census count was completed in 1790
column3: New York City had already grown to be 14% more populous than Philadelphia (though Philadelphia still had the larger metropolitan population in 1790). Note that
column5: New York City consisted of the entire island of Manhattan and that Philadelphia only included the most central neighborhoods of the city.

column2: 869. Last time Massachusetts has two cities in the top ten.

column2: the United States was in the midst of the First Industrial Revolution.

column1: The total population of these 10 cities was 1
1860 was the eve of the American Civil War. This was the eighth United States Census.  This is the first census where the Northeast does not hold a supermajority of the top ten largest cities.
The total population of these 10 cities was 2

This was the ninth United States Census. This is the first census where the Northeast does not hold a simple majority of the top ten largest cities (briefly returns to 5 top cities in the 1910 Census).
The total population of these 10 cities was 3
The total population of these 10 cities was 4
The 1890 Census was the Eleventh. Four Midwest cities occupied the top ten spots
column2: with two cities from Ohio in the top ten for the first time.

column1: The total population of these 10 cities was 6
The 1900 Census was the Twelfth.
The total population of these 10 cities was 9
The 1910 Census was the Thirteenth.
The total population of these 10 cities was 12
The 1920 Census was the Fourteenth. Only time three midwestern cities occupy the top five.
The total population of these 10 cities was 15
The 1930 Census was the Fifteenth.
The total population of these 10 cities was 19
Four of the ten cities here would have their first ever population drop in 1940.  Though slight
column2: they would presage a precipitous decline that started in 1950.  The 1940 Census was the Sixteenth.

column1: The total population of these 10 cities was 19
1950 was a watershed year for many cities in the United States. Many cities in the country peaked in population
column2: and began a slow decline caused by suburbanization associated with pollution
column4: and increased crime rates in inner cities
column5: while the improved infrastructure of the Eisenhower Interstate System more easily facilitated car commutes and white flight of the white middle class.  The G.I. Bill made available low interest loans for returning World War II veterans seeking more commodious housing in the suburbs. Although populations within city limits dropped in many American cities
column6: the metropolitan populations of most cities continued to increase greatly.

column1: The total population of these 10 cities was 21
The 1960 Census was the Eighteenth.  This was the first census (see also 1980) to show a decline in the combined total population of top ten cities
column3: 495 (3.5%) fewer people than 1950 Census' top ten cities.

column1: The total population of these 10 cities was 20
The 1970 Census was the Nineteenth.
The total population of these 10 cities was 22

column2: the trends towards suburbanization started in the 1950s continued.  This was the second census (see also 1960) to show a decline in the combined total population of the top ten cities
column5: 003 (5.2%) fewer people than the 1970 Census' top ten cities. This is the first census in which half of the top ten cities are in the Sun Belt
column6: specifically the West South Central and South Western area of the country.

column1: The total population of these 10 cities was 20

The 1990 Census was the Twenty-first.  Continued trends of western cities' growth and Northeastern cities' contraction now place a majority of the top ten cities in the western portion of the Sun Belt
column2: a regional concentration not seen since Northeastern cities dominated the top of the first seven censuses.

column1: The total population of these 10 cities was 21
The 2000 Census was the 22nd in U.S. history.
The total population of these 10 cities was 23
Seven of the country's ten largest cities in 2010 were located in the Sun Belt region of the south and west
column2: all of which have far lower population density than their earlier top-ranking counterparts. A different ranking is evident when considering U.S. metro area populations which count both city and suburban populations.
